intro: Ferulago insularis, commonly known as the island ferulago, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of the Mediterranean. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its distinctive umbellate inflorescence. The plant typically grows in rocky or coastal areas, adapting to harsh environmental conditions. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, while its small white flowers bloom in clusters, contributing to its ornamental value. Ferulago insularis is relatively rare and is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological niche.
